name: St. Alphonsus Liguori

locations.description: Founder of the Redemptorists, Bishop of Sant'Agata dei Goti

summary: Alphonsus Liguori was an Italian Catholic bishop, spiritual writer, composer, musician, artist, poet, lawyer, scholastic philosopher, and theologian. He founded the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer (Redemptorists) in 1732. He is best known for his moral theology, particularly his work on casuistry and probabilism. He was declared a Doctor of the Church in 1871 and is the patron saint of confessors, moral theologians, and vocations.
keyQuotes: He who does not acquire the love of God will scarcely persevere in the grace of God, for it is very difficult to renounce sin merely through fear of chastisement.
The more a person loves God, the more reason he has to hope in Him.

name: St. Paul of the Cross
summary: Paul of the Cross was an Italian mystic and the founder of the Passionists, a religious order dedicated to preaching about the Passion of Christ. He received visions and experienced mystical phenomena throughout his life. He established the first Passionist monastery in 1737 and spent his life preaching missions and retreats throughout Italy, emphasizing the love of God shown through Christ's suffering.
keyQuotes: It is very good and holy to consider the passion of our Lord and to meditate on it, for by this sacred path we reach union with God.

name: St. Leonard of Port Maurice

locations.description: Franciscan preacher, popularized the Stations of the Cross

summary: Leonard of Port Maurice was an Italian Franciscan friar and preacher. He is best known for popularizing the devotion of the Stations of the Cross throughout Italy. He preached missions throughout Italy and was known for his powerful preaching on penance and the Passion of Christ. He established the Stations of the Cross in over 500 locations throughout Italy.

name: St. Benedict Joseph Labre

locations.description: Homeless pilgrim, known as the 'Beggar of Rome'

summary: Benedict Joseph Labre was a French mendicant and pilgrim who became known as the 'Beggar of Rome' and the 'Saint of the Forty Hours.' After failing to join several religious orders due to poor health, he became a wandering pilgrim, traveling to major shrines throughout Europe. He spent the last years of his life in Rome, living in poverty and dedicating himself to prayer and adoration of the Blessed Sacrament.

name: Bl. Luis de Velasco
summary: Luis de Velasco was a Spanish Augustinian priest who was martyred during the French Revolution. He was one of many priests and religious who refused to take the oath to the Civil Constitution of the Clergy and were executed for their fidelity to the Church. He was beatified as one of the Martyrs of the French Revolution.

name: Pope Clement XI
summary: Clement XI was pope from 1700 to 1721. His pontificate was marked by conflicts with European powers, particularly over Jansenism and the Chinese Rites Controversy. He issued the bull Unigenitus (1713) condemning Jansenism and Ex illa die (1715) prohibiting the Chinese rites. He was a patron of the arts and learning, supporting the Vatican Library and commissioning works of art.

name: Pope Benedict XIV
summary: Benedict XIV was pope from 1740 to 1758. He was one of the most learned popes of the 18th century, known for his scholarship and administrative reforms. He worked to improve relations with European powers while maintaining Church doctrine. He definitively settled the Chinese Rites Controversy with Ex quo singulari (1742). He was a patron of learning and the arts, and he reformed the procedures for beatification and canonization.

name: Pope Pius VI

locations.description: Pope from 1775 to 1799, died in French captivity

summary: Pius VI was pope from 1775 to 1799, the longest pontificate up to that time. His reign was marked by the suppression of the Jesuits (which he was unable to prevent), the French Revolution, and the French invasion of the Papal States. He condemned the Civil Constitution of the Clergy and was taken prisoner by French forces in 1798. He died in exile in France, the first pope to die outside Italy in over a thousand years.

name: Pope Clement XIV

locations.description: Pope from 1769 to 1774, suppressed the Jesuits

summary: Clement XIV was pope from 1769 to 1774. Under intense pressure from Catholic monarchs, particularly the Bourbon courts of France, Spain, and Portugal, he issued the brief Dominus ac Redemptor in 1773, suppressing the Society of Jesus throughout the Catholic world. This was one of the most controversial acts of the 18th-century papacy and had lasting consequences for Catholic missions and education.

name: St. Junípero Serra

locations.description: Franciscan missionary, founded missions in California

summary: Junípero Serra was a Spanish Franciscan friar who founded a series of missions in California from 1769 to 1782. He established nine of the 21 Spanish missions in California, including San Diego, San Francisco, and Santa Barbara. He is credited with bringing Christianity to thousands of Native Americans, though his legacy is also controversial due to the impact of Spanish colonization on indigenous peoples. He was canonized by Pope Francis in 2015.
